document_title: Fournier syndrome: Causes, symptoms, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
Anaerobic or aerobic bacteria can cause Fournier syndrome. Some common types include: (2)
E. coli (Escherichia coli).; Klebsiella.; Proteus.; Staphylococcus.; Streptococcus.; Clostridium.; Peptostreptococcus.
Bacteria can enter the rectum and genital organs in many different ways, including:
Abscess.; Anal fistula and diverticulitis.; Bladder or urinary tract infection; Injury causing scratches or burns; Insect bite.; Rectal cancer.; Sex.; Ulcers.; Circumcision (in children).
The danger elements
Patients being treated with immunosuppressive drugs; People with liver disease, leukemia, lupus.; People with Crohn's disease; People infected with HIV.; The patient is undergoing chemotherapy.; Patients undergoing long-term treatment with Corticosteroid drugs; People with malnutrition or severe obesity; Old age.
